import React from 'react'; import './Notes.css'; const NutritionInPlantsNotes: React.FC = () => { return (

Chapter 1: Nutrition in Plants

Introduction to Nutrition

All living organisms need food to survive, grow, and carry out life processes. Food provides the energy required for various activities. Nutrients are the components of food, such as carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals, that are essential for our bodies.

Did You Know?

Nutrition is the process of taking in food and its utilization by the body.

Modes of Nutrition

There are two main modes of nutrition in organisms:

  • Autotrophic Nutrition: Organisms that make their own food from simple substances are called autotrophs. Green plants are autotrophs.
  • Heterotrophic Nutrition: Organisms that depend on other organisms for food are called heterotrophs. Animals and humans are examples of heterotrophs.

Photosynthesis: Food-Making Process in Plants

Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants prepare their own food.

Requirements for Photosynthesis:

  • Sunlight: The ultimate source of energy.
  • Chlorophyll: The green pigment in leaves that traps sunlight.
  • Carbon Dioxide: Taken from the atmosphere through stomata.
  • Water and Minerals: Absorbed from the soil by the roots.

Photosynthesis Equation:

Carbon Dioxide + Water (in the presence of Sunlight and Chlorophyll) â†’ Carbohydrate + Oxygen

Other Modes of Nutrition in Plants

Mode of Nutrition Description Example
Parasitic Obtain food from a host organism. Cuscuta (Amarbel)
Insectivorous Feed on insects. Pitcher Plant
Saprotrophic Obtain nutrients from dead and decaying matter. Fungi
Symbiotic Two organisms live together for mutual benefit. Lichens (alga and fungus)

Replenishment of Nutrients in the Soil

Continuous farming can deplete essential nutrients from the soil. These can be replenished by:

  • Adding fertilizers and manures.
  • Nitrogen fixation by bacteria like Rhizobium in leguminous plants.

Remember Rhizobium!

Rhizobium bacteria are like little fertilizer factories for plants!

Summary

  • Nutrition is the process of taking in and using food.
  • Plants are mostly autotrophs, making their own food via photosynthesis.
  • Photosynthesis requires sunlight, chlorophyll, carbon dioxide, and water.
  • Some plants are heterotrophs (parasitic, insectivorous, saprotrophic).
  • Symbiotic relationships involve mutual benefit.
  • Soil nutrients are replenished by fertilizers, manures, and nitrogen fixation.
); }; export default NutritionInPlantsNotes;
